name: Kevin Durant
politicalViews: Durant has stayed out of politics, except for when he once met Barack Obama.
author: Tom Kershaw

content.text: Kevin Durant was born and raised in the Washington D.C. area.

content.sourceTitle: NBA All-Star Kevin Durant on faith, family and fame
content.text: Durant is one of basketball and even professional sports' most devout Christians. Durant attended a Christian school growing up and even now, amidst the fortune and fame, regularly attends church services before games.

content.sourceTitle: Oklahoma City Thunder's Kevin Durant draws closer to God
content.text: Durant carries a Bible in a backpack to his post-game interviews, and thanks God for his blessings as a star basketball playerâ€“even when he loses.
Durant credits his faith and humility to his mother and various other spiritual "coaches" and says things like:

content.sourceTitle: NBA All-Star Kevin Durant on faith, family and fame
content.text: I've got a long way to go to become closer to the Lord but hopefully I can continue to stay on the path. I might take a few steps forward and take a couple steps back and take some steps forward, but I want to get better.

Durant isn't too political. Maybe his overwhelming humility prevents him from taking a stand on anything. More often than not, being a hardcore Christian pits people against the socially liberal policies of the left (gay marriage, abortion, etc.), though Durant hasn't said anything about these issues. On the other hand, being a black American almost requires you to support Barack Obama.
And Durant and Obama sure looked chummy during a White House meeting, where they shared a bro hug. Check out the . Durant said of the meeting:

It was a good feeling to meet the president. Of course I always wanted to do that. Me being from D.C., it was pretty cool to see him. I was excited to get that opportunity. It's something I'm always going to remember.
Still, that doesn't indicate anything except that Durant doesn't despise Obama for his policies.
